name: Grand Canyon National Park
description: Grand Canyon National Park, located in northern Arizona, preserves one of the most iconic geological formations on Earth — the immense Grand Canyon carved by the Colorado River over millions of years. The canyon reveals nearly two billion years of Earth’s geological history in its colorful rock layers and offers stunning vistas from both the North and South Rims.

geology.summary: The Grand Canyon exposes rock formations dating from the Precambrian to the Paleozoic eras. Its creation was driven by uplift of the Colorado Plateau and erosion from the Colorado River.

wildlife.description: The park supports over 1,500 plant species and more than 450 species of animals, including several that are endemic to the region.

locations.name: South Rim
locations.description: The most accessible and visited part of the park, featuring popular viewpoints such as Mather Point and Desert View.

locations.name: North Rim
locations.description: Higher and cooler than the South Rim, offering quieter experiences and unique perspectives of the canyon.

locations.name: Bright Angel Trail
locations.description: One of the park’s most famous hiking routes descending from the South Rim to the Colorado River.

locations.name: Phantom Ranch
locations.description: A historic lodge located at the bottom of the canyon near the Colorado River, accessible only by foot, mule, or raft.

locations.name: Desert View Watchtower
locations.description: A 21-meter stone tower designed by architect Mary Colter, offering expansive views of the eastern canyon.

locations.name: Grand Canyon Village
locations.description: Historic hub of visitor activity on the South Rim, home to lodges, the visitor center, and the Grand Canyon Railway depot.

locations.name: Hermit's Rest
locations.description: A historic rest house located at the end of the Hermit Road, offering panoramic views of the canyon.

locations.name: Grandview Point
locations.description: A viewpoint offering expansive views of the canyon, accessible via the Grandview Trail.

locations.name: Yaki Point
locations.description: A viewpoint offering panoramic views of the canyon, accessible via the South Kaibab Trail.

locations.name: Tusayan Ruins and Museum
locations.description: An archaeological site preserving the ruins of an ancient Puebloan village.

trails.name: Bright Angel Trail
trails.description: A challenging trail descending 15 km from the South Rim to the Colorado River with rest stops along the way.

trails.name: South Kaibab Trail
trails.description: A scenic trail offering expansive views, descending 14.5 km from the South Rim to the Colorado River.

trails.name: North Kaibab Trail
trails.description: The only maintained trail into the canyon from the North Rim, connecting to Phantom Ranch and Bright Angel Trail.

trails.name: Rim Trail
trails.description: A mostly paved trail following the South Rim from the Village to Hermit’s Rest, offering numerous viewpoints.

trails.name: Tonto Trail
trails.description: A trail crossing the Tonto Platform approximately 3900 ft (1200 m) below the South Rim, intersecting both the Bright Angel and South Kaibab Trails.

trails.name: Grandview Trail
trails.description: A steep trail offering dramatic views of the canyon, descending from Grandview Point.

trails.name: Hermit's Rest Trail
trails.description: A trail leading from Hermit's Rest to the end of Hermit Road, offering scenic views along the way.

trails.name: Yaki Point Trail
trails.description: A trail leading from Yaki Point to the end of the South Kaibab Trail, offering panoramic views.

trails.name: Trail of Time
trails.description: A relatively flat 4.56 km (2.83 mile) long paved walk designed as a geologic timeline.

safety_tips: Carry and drink plenty of water; dehydration is a major hazard.
Avoid hiking during midday heat in summer.
Stay at least 1.2 meters away from the edge of the canyon rim.
Use sunscreen and wear protective clothing.
Inform others of your hiking plans before descending below the rim.
